Award.AwardTitle: Research Initiation Award: Arsenic speciation in sulfidic environments

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research Initiation Awards provide support for junior and mid-career faculty at Historically Black Colleges and Universities who are building new research programs or redirecting and rebuilding existing research programs. It is expected that the award helps to further the faculty member's research capability and effectiveness, improves research and teaching at his home institution, and involves undergraduate students in research experiences. The project at Voorhees College has potential broader impacts in a number of areas. The goal of the project is develop an analytical methodology for the speciation analysis of various arsenic species in the natural environment, particularly those with high sulfide levels. The project will also enhance the research experience and training of undergraduate students at Voorhees College and promises to provide collaboration between the College and the local community through public education and environmental monitoring services for municipal facilities.

Commonly encountered arsenic species in natural aquatic environments include arsenite, arsenate , monomethylarsonic acid, and dimethylarsinic acid. Another type of arsenic species,thioarsenates, has been found recently in environments with high sulfide levels. This project seeks the simultaneous detection of thioarsenate species and common inorganic and organic arsenic species, which has not been previously reported. The project will consist of three stages. First liquid chromatographic techniques will be explored to determine their suitability for the separation and analysis of both inorganic and organic arsenic analysis. A methodology based on chromatography and mass spectrometry will be developed and validated. Then, laboratory experiments will be conducted to analyze arsenic speciation in simulated sulfidic waters, and finally field samples will be collected and analyzed to investigate the fate of arsenic in real sulfidic environments. The occurrence mechanisms and the results on the fate and transport of thioarsenate species will provide helpful background for the development of strategies in controlling and remediating arsenic mobilization in a sulfidic environment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goal of the project is to develop analytical chemistry methods to identify and measure the different chemical forms of arsenic (including four arsenic species and four thioarsenic species) existing in natural or engineered environment where the level of sulfide concentration is high. The methods were based on chromatography, which is a chemical separation technique separating specific forms of molecules, and mass spectrometry, which is another instrumental tool for the trace analysis of chemicals. In addition, the project also has educational goals to provide hands-on research experiences in environmental and analytical chemistry for undergraduate students and therefore facilitating the growth of the recently established Environmental Science program at Voorhees College.

Two chromatographic methods were explored – liquid chromatography (LC) and ion chromatography (IC). For LC, the separation of arsenic species were achieved on a ThermoScientific WAX­1 mixed mode column and a Hamilton PRP-X100 Anion Exchange HPLC Column. Optimization of the LC conditions was performed by adjusting the solvent, pH of the mobile phase, and the buffer solution. The chromatographic separation on the Anion Exchange column was able to separate arsenic and thioarsenic species, however, with relatively long run time of more than 80 minutes. Thioarsenic species were shown to have much longer retention times on LC columns than other arsenic species. IC methods, on the other hand, showed more efficient separation of the arsenic and thioarsenic species. Mass spectrometry (MS) analysis was performed by both direct infusion into the mass spectrometry and connecting the IC and mass spectrometry, which were able to detect the arsenic species.

The project has contributed significantly to undergraduate students training. There were seven minority undergraduate students that participated the project. These students have received training on multiple skills (such as quantitative calculations related to solutions and concentrations, chromatography principles, and etc.) and gained hands-on research experience. Among the students who have graduated, at least two students went to graduate schools for further STEM study. Nine conference papers have been submitted to and accepted by national research conferences. Students have presented the results at the conferences.
